importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news report indicates the timing of the flooding event and the ongoing humanitarian response, highlighting the urgency and recent impact of the disaster.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding occurred last week, which establishes the temporal context for the disaster and the timeline of the response efforts.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding in five states.
The state of Veracruz reported 29 deaths, followed by Hidalgo (21), Puebla (13), and Queretaro (1).
65 people remain missing, including 43 in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
Over 100,000 homes have been affected, with some near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain, respectively.
Thousands of military personnel, including Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have deployed to deliver food, clean water, and aid to isolated areas.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of the electricity supply across five states, where about 263,000 users lost power.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported the death and missing tolls during President Claudia Sheinbaum’s daily briefing.
President Claudia Sheinbaum acknowledged the lack of early meteorological warnings that could have indicated the severity of the rainfall.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In Mexico, heavy rains caused by the remnants of Hurricanes Priscilla and Raymond led to deadly flooding in five states, resulting in at least 64 deaths and 65 missing people. The hardest-hit areas were Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), and Puebla (13 deaths). The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso. Thousands of military personnel, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to deliver food, clean water, and emergency aid. Over 100,000 homes were affected, with some severely damaged or destroyed. Despite efforts to restore power—nearly 80% of electricity service was restored—government officials acknowledged the lack of early warning signs indicating the severity of the rainfall, raising questions about Mexico’s disaster preparedness and meteorological alert systems.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
